At this time of the year the retail trade is hit especially hard by members of the shoplifting community. According to a report on the BBC, about 3.5 million people have been caught stealing from shops in the last 5 years (in Britain). 
 
 The list of items favored by shoplifters is pretty weird. At the top of the list is razor blades, followed by air fresheners and batteries. Toothbrushes are another popular item. More predictable stuff - which is taken virtually wholesale and on a "professional" basis - are cosmetics, alcohol, lingerie, CDs, and DVDs. 
 
 Shopkeepers affect to be terribly concerned about this "scourge" of thieving. Since an estimated cost of their shoplifting losses is factored into retail prices, it's the consumer who picks up the tab.

 If you take a small toy shop "up market" and sell only expensive wooden toys imported from Scandinavia - or designed there and manufactured in Thailand - the incidence of theft drops. The toy thieves don't want quality products; their kids crave every lump of rubbish that is marketed on TV.
